And as they entered the village, the women began to sing. But the song was not for Ikemefuna, nor for the youths of Umuofia. It was a song of men's work and their hopes for the harvest. And though they were all young men, and many a girl gazed at them with yearning, the young men went into the men's house without looking at the women.

The Newgate Calendar, or The Malefactors' Bloody Register... is an English collection of brief biographies of executed criminals, printed in six editions from 1774 to 1868. The series title refers to Newgate prison in London, which at that time held the capital's main prison, and which was eventually closed in 1902.

Boswell's Life of Johnson (1817) is a biography of Samuel Johnson, the English writer and lexicographer. Johnson wrote the book, and Sir John Hawkins provided editorial supervision of the published edition. The biographers were not always complementary in their depictions of Johnson; some later biographers, such as Henry Hallam, were critical of Boswell. Boswell later published in three volumes his An Account of Corsica.

She had, it was true, her moments of depression when she would snap at everybody like an angry dog. These moods descended on her suddenly and for no apparent reason. The story opens in Maycomb, Alabama in 1926, when black man, Tom Robinson, is accused of rape by two young white girls. Atticus Finch has long been an outspoken critic of this injustice, but it appears as though a jury may side with the two girls. The jury members are black people, but they will be unable to render a just verdict because they are intimidated by the white men of the town.

The jury is composed of black people, but they are not able to render a just verdict, simply because they were intimidated by the white people in the town.

This shows us that these black people were too fearful to do what was right. Atticus does not want to fight a mob on behalf of Tom Robinson, so he is going to try to have him acquitted in the court of law.

input: something behind it, though. Maycomb was an ancient town. It was twenty miles east of Finch's Landing, awkwardly inland for such an old town. But Maycomb would have been closer to the river had it not been for the nimble-wittedness of one Sinkfield, who in the dawn of history operated an inn where two pig-trails met, the only tavern in the territory. Sinkfield, no patriot, served and supplied ammunition to Indians and settlers alike, neither knowing or caring whether he was a part of the Alabama Territory or the Creek Nation so long as business was good. Business was excellent when Governor William Wyatt Bibb, with a view to promoting the newly created county's domestic tranquility, dispatched a team of surveyors to locate its exact center and there establish its seat of government. The surveyors, Sinkfield's guests, told their host that he was in the territorial confines of Maycomb County, and showed him the probable spot where the county seat would be built. Had not Sinkfield made a bold stroke to preserve his holdings
reference: , Maycomb would have sat in the middle of Winston Swamp, a place totally devoid of interest. Instead, Maycomb grew and sprawled out from its hub, Sinkfield's Tavern, because Sinkfield reduced his guests to myopic drunkenness one evening, induced them to bring forward their maps and charts, lop off a
output:
, the seat would have been in Bibb County, named for the governor. Sinkfield had a cabin at the crossroads. When the surveyors pointed out his house, Sinkfield is said to have replied: "Well, if you gentlemen want to do business here, I'll just move into my cabin in the woods and you'll never see me or hear of me again." The surveyors, knowing that they had to have the most central location in the county, gave up their efforts to induce him to move. So in 1799 the town was laid out and Sinkfield kept his land. Maycomb prospered and became a trading center. After Sinkfield had removed his cabin from the spot, the town grew around a crossroads at a bend of the river.

The rural children who could, usually brought clippings from what they called The Grit Paper, a publication spurious in the eyes of Miss Gates, our teacher. Why she frowned when a child recited from The Grit Paper I never knew, but in some way it was associated with liking fiddling, eating syrupy biscuits for lunch, being a holy-roller, singing Sweetly Sings the Donkey and pronouncing it dunkey, all of which the state paid teachers to discourage. considered the town boy who knew everything in Maycomb, including which were the Current Events that would prove most useful in quiz shows and what sort of answer to give to the question, _'What is the capital of South Carolina?'_ He would not tell us. The boy who seemed least intelligent and most likely to be flunked, whose very name was a synonym for dullness, was the child who supplied the right answer to this question. If he knew the capital of South Carolina, he knew everything. He would be able to identify the capital of any other South Carolina. Even Miss Gates, who had no patience with the boy, conceded that such a fact was the sort to have in the mind of a person who wanted to be a lawyer. In possession of his court once more, Judge Taylor leaned back in his chair. He looked suddenly weary; his age was showing, and I thought about what Atticus had said- he and Mrs. Taylor didn't kiss much- he must have been nearly seventy. "There has been a request," Judge Taylor said, "that this courtroom be cleared of spectators, or at least of women and children, a request that will be denied for the time being. The air was so cold and clear we heard the courthouse clock clank, rattle and strain before it struck the hour. Miss Maudie's nose was a color I had never seen before, and I inquired about it. That's what was the matter with the cake. I never would have gave her any of our cake to eat if I had known in time, but she had a craving for it, and by the time I figured it out and found a substitute, it was too late. That's when I made that Lane cake. But not a mouthful of that had I, so it don't count. Not but what I'm sorry, too. I'd just as soon have her eat none of the cake as no Lane cake, and that's the truth."

We call this the opening sentence.

He went the back way, through Deer's Pasture, across the schoolyard and around to the fence, I thought- at least that was the way he was headed. It would take longer, so it was not time to worry yet. I waited until it was time to worry and listened for Mr. Radley's shotgun. Then I thought I heard the back fence squeak. It was wishful thinking. Then I heard Atticus cough. I held my breath. I waited at the corner of the house until I heard the snarl of the Packard's engine and the tires crushing gravel. I went to the window by the kitchen door. The Packard stopped, and Jem was out before it had quite stopped. He went through the gate and in the direction of town. He would have to pass the old Radley place.
